metadata.title: Kinetic features of ethylene polymerization over titanium-magnesium Ziegler-Natta catalysts: Effect of monomer concentration on the number of active centers and propagation rate constant

Fig. 1 Effect of ethylene pressure on polymerization rate over TMC under study. Arrows show the moment of 14CO introduction. Fig. 2 The order of the polymerization rate with respect to ethylene concentration for TMC in experiments with polymerization quenching by 14CO. Polymerization rate at the moment of 14CO introduction was used to calculate the order values. Fig. 3 Polymerization rate vs. time for TMC-2 catalyst at the ethylene pressure change in single experiment (Table 1, run 7). The arrow shows the moment of 14CO introduction. Fig. 4 MWD curves of polyethylene produced over TMC-2 catalysts at different ethylene pressure (runs from Table 1). Fig. 5 Effect of ethylene pressure on polymerization rate for TMC-2 catalyst in experiments with different AlEt3 concentration (runs from Table 2). Arrows show the moment of 14CO introduction. Fig. 6 Effect of ethylene pressure on MWD of polyethylene produced over TMC-2 catalysts at different AlEt3 concentrations (runs from Table 2). Scheme 1 Transformation of the active centers at ethylene polymerization over TMC under investigation. Table 1 Effect of ethylene pressure on the number of active centers (C P), propagation rate constants (k P) and molecular-weight characteristics of polyethylene produced over TMC with different composition. Run No. a Catalyst Ethylene pressure (bar) R b , (kg(PE) molTi −1 h−1 bar−1) C P, (molmolTi −1) k P, (Lmol−1 s−1) M n, (kgmol−1) M w, (kgmol−1) M w/M n c 1 TMC-1 (1wt. % of Ti) 1 7800 0.11 13,120 2 4 18,100 0.24 13,900 1600 d 3 TMC-2 (0.12wt. % of Ti) 0.5 10,380 0.16 12,250 4.8 180 38 4 1 21,830 0.20 20,280 16 330 21 5 2 43,190 0.24 32,870 40 400 10 6 4 72,490 0.40 33,400 72 470 6.5 7 4→1 19,700 0.22 16,630 a 80°C; [AlEt3]=4.5mmolL−1; kinetic curves are presented in Figs. 1 and 3. b Polymerization rate at the moment of 14CO introduction. c MWD curves are presented in Fig. 4. d The viscosity average molecular weight (M v), calculated from intrinsic viscosity of PE (η). Table 2 Effect of ethylene pressure on the C P and k P values and molecular-weight characteristics of polyethylene produced over TMC-2 catalyst in experiments with different AlEt3 concentration. Run No. a [AlEt3] (mmol/L) Ethylene pressure (bar) R b , (kg(PE) molTi −1 h−1 bar−1) C P, (molmolTi −1) k P, (Lmol−1 s−1) M n c , (kgmol−1) M w c , (kgmol−1) M w/M n 1 4.5 2 43,190 0.24 32,870 40 400 10 2 4 72,490 0.4 33,400 72 470 6.5 3 9.0 2 20,340 0.24 15,900 8.2 270 33 4 4 35,070 0.26 23,580 17 340 20 a Polymerization conditions as in Table 1; kinetic curves are presented in Fig. 5. b Polymerization rate at the moment of 14CO introduction. c MWD curves are presented in Fig. 6. Kinetic features of ethylene polymerization over titanium-magnesium Ziegler-Natta catalysts: Effect of monomer concentration on the number of active centers and propagation rate constant Artem A. Barabanov a ⁎ Viktoria V. Sukulova a Mikhail A. Matsko a Vladimir A. Zakharov a b a Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS, pr. academika Lavrentieva, 5, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS pr. academika Lavrentieva, 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia b Novosibirsk State Univercity, Pirogova., 2, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russia Novosibirsk State Univercity Pirogova., 2 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +7 3833269770; fax: +7 3833308056. Graphical abstract It was found that the observed order of the polymerization rate with respect to ethylene concentration at ethylene polymerization over two titanium-magnesium catalysts of different compositions is significantly higher than 1 (1.6–2.1). The data on the effect of ethylene concentration on the number of active centers (C P) and the propagation rate constant (k P) at ethylene polymerization over these catalysts were obtained by method of polymerization quenching with 14CO. An increase in ethylene concentration was found to increase the number of active centers. In some cases the increase of ethylene concentration proceeds to the narrowing of the molecular weight distribution of the resulting polyethylene and an increase in the calculated value of propagation rate constant. These effects were shown to be most pronounced at low ethylene pressure and increased concentration of an activator (AlEt3). Based on the experimental data, we proposed a scheme of reactions to explain the effects of ethylene and AlR3 concentrations on the number of active centers, the average values of propagation rate constant and molecular weight distribution of polymers produced over these multi-site catalysts. Keywords Ethylene polymerization Polymerization kinetics Propagation rate constant Number of active centers Ziegler-Natta catalysts 1 Introduction Studying the kinetics of olefin polymerization over modern highly active supported titanium-magnesium catalysts (TMC) is an important step towards understanding the mechanism of action of these systems. A number of reviews have been devoted to the analysis of the kinetic features of olefin polymerization over Ziegler-Natta catalysts [1–6]. However, some kinetic findings remain uninterpreted because of the versatility of the catalysts of this type, complex composition of the active component, several types of active centers, and changes they undergo during polymerization. In particular, dependence of the polymerization rate on monomer concentration is a key feature of polymerization. According to the two-stage mechanism of the propagation reaction at catalytic polymerization proposed by Cossee [7], the propagation rate can be linearly dependent on monomer concentration and described by the first-order equation. Indeed, these dependences were observed in a large number of studies devoted to olefin polymerization over different catalysts [1–6]. However, some studies showed that a mixed (between the first and second) order of the polymerization rate with respect to ethylene is observed at low ethylene pressure [8–12]. Several hypotheses have been proposed to interpret this effect. Thus, Ystenes proposed the so-called “trigger” mechanism of the propagation reaction suggesting that an ethylene molecule coordinated on titanium ion at the titanium–polymer bond is inserted when the active center interacts with the second ethylene molecule [13,14]. The features of the “trigger” mechanism were also discussed by other authors [9,15–17]. A number of studies suggested that the observed second order of the polymerization rate with respect to monomer is due to the presence of a slow initiation stage, which occurs when a monomer interacts with the precursor of active centers containing the titanium–alkyl bond [18–20]. Resconi et al. suggested that the centers with different reactivities with respect to monomer may differ in conformation of the growing polymer chain (agostic interactions of β- and γ-hydrogen and titanium atom) [21,22]. The assumptions in the existing literature regarding the reasons for the observed shift in the order of the polymerization rate with respect to monomer (from the first towards the second order) are insufficiently substantiated by the experimental data. In this work, we experimentally studied the effect of ethylene concentration on the number of active centers (C P) and the propagation rate constant (k P) at ethylene polymerization over modern highly active TMC designed in our laboratory. The data on the effect of ethylene concentration on these kinetic parameters were obtained for the first time; these data provide better supported explanation for the shift in the order of the polymerization rate with respect to monomer from the first towards the second order. When analyzing the data on the effect of ethylene concentration on the calculated k P value, we additionally used the experimental findings on the effect of ethylene concentration on the molecular weight distribution of the resulting polymer. Based on the experimental data, we proposed a scheme of the reactions occurring upon formation and transformation of active centers at polymerization. This scheme explains the nonlinear dependence of the polymerization rate on monomer concentration and formation of dormant sites, whose number depends on concentration of ethylene and organoaluminum activator. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts The support of TMC-1 catalyst (S-1) was prepared by interaction of PhSiCl3 with organomagnesium compound Mg3Ph4Cl2 dissolved in diisoamyl ether [23]. The support for TMC-2 catalyst (S-2) was synthesized by interaction of the organomagnesium compound Mg3Ph4Cl2 solution in dibutyl ether with the mixture of PhSiCl3 and Si(OEt)4 [24]. Support S-2 was additionally treated with a solution of diethylaluminum chloride in heptane at 40°C and molar ratio Al/Mg=1.5 and then washed with CCl4 to convert adsorbed AlEt2Cl into AlCl3. The catalyst TMC-1 was synthesized by supporting titanium tetrachloride on magnesium chloride support S-1 at 60°C and molar ratio TiCl4/Mg=1. The catalyst TMC-2 was prepared by deposition of calculated amount of titanium tetrachloride on magnesium-containing support S-2 modified by AlCl3. For the catalysts TMC-1 and TMC-2, the titanium content (determined by AES-ICP) was equal to 1.0 and 0.12wt. %, correspondingly. The obtained catalysts had a spherical shape with the average particle size of 5–6μm and a narrow particle size distribution. 2.2 Ethylene polymerization The polymerization runs were performed in a steel 0.5L reactor. A sealed glass ampoule with suspension of a catalyst in heptane (5–8mg) was placed into the reactor. The reactor was heated at 80°C under vacuum for 1.5h and cooled to 20°C. Then the reactor was filled with 150mL of heptane and 2-4mL of AlEt3 solution in heptane ([AlEt3] in the reactor was 4.5–9.0mmol/L). The reaction mixture was heated to the desired temperature (80°C) and saturated with ethylene (0.5–4.0bar). The reaction was started by breaking an ampoule with the catalyst. During polymerization, the ethylene pressure was maintained constant through an automatic computer-controlled system for the ethylene feed; the ethylene consumption to the reaction medium was measured a few seconds apart. The temperature in the reactor was permanently measured by a thermocell and kept constant through water-jacket cooling. After a prescribed time, the reactor was vented, and the obtained solid product was separated and then dried under ambient conditions to the constant weight. The polymerization rate was calculated according to ethylene consumption taking into account the weight of the obtained polymer. 2.3 Determination of the number of active centers (C P) and the propagation rate constant (k P) Polymerization quenching by 14CO was used to determine the C P and k P values. We used this method earlier to study ethylene and propylene polymerization over traditional Ziegler-Natta catalysts (TiCl3/AlEt3) [25–27] and supported titanium-magnesium [28–31] catalysts. The detailed description of the method of polymerization quenching by 14CO is given in refs.[32–35] Most studies involving this method were conducted when studying propylene polymerization [28–31,35,36]. There are much fewer data on determining the C P and k P values at ethylene polymerization [30,31,37]. The conditions used for polymerization quenching (the amount of 14CO and duration of quenching (τ CO)) were the same as those used earlier [28,35] for TMC: 14CO/Ti=15–20, τ CO =15min. The polymer samples were purified from the labeled by-products by double reprecipitation from undecane using the procedure described in ref. [35]. An Intertechnique SL-4000 scintillation counter was used to measure polymer radioactivity. The number of active centers (C P) was determined based on radioactivity of PE. The propagation rate constant (k P) was calculated from Eq. (1) (1) k P = R × C P − 1 × C 2 H 4 − 1 where R is the polymerization rate at the moment of 14CO introduction and [C2H4] is the ethylene concentration in heptane, which was calculated using the Henry's constant [38]. 2.4 Polymers characterization GPC measurements were performed using a PL 220C instrument with RI and DV detectors. Run conditions were as follows: 160°C; 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene (TCB) was used as a solvent at a flow rate of 1cm3 min−1. A set of Olexis-gel columns was employed. Calibration was performed using PS and PE standards with narrow MWD. Viscosity (η) of the polymers was measured in decalin at 135°C on an Ubbelohde viscosimeter. The viscosity average molecular weight M v was calculated according to the Mark–Houwink equation: (2) M v = η × K − 1 × α − 1 , where the Mark–Hauwink coefficients are K =67.7×10−5 and α =0.67 [39]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of monomer concentration on the C P and k P values and molecular-weight characteristics of the resulting polyethylene Table 1 list the data on C P and k P values for ethylene polymerization at different monomer pressures (in the range of 0.5–4bar) for TMC-1 and TMC-2 catalysts. Fig. 1 shows the kinetic profile of the polymerization rate in these experiments. Let us mention that TMC-1 and TMC-2 catalysts differ in the way they were prepared, support composition, and content of the active component (titanium). In particular, TMC-2 catalyst contains OEt moieties and has a very low titanium content (0.12wt. %). This catalyst is characterized by a significantly higher activity per one atom of titanium [40] compared with TMC-1 catalyst and produces polyethylene with a lower molecular weight (compare data on molecular weight of polymers in runs 2 and 6 in Table 1). Having plotted the dependence of the polymerization rate on monomer concentration at the moment of 14CO introduction (when the steady-state rate is achieved) in rectifying coordinates, we determined the order of the polymerization rate with respect to monomer (n value), which is higher than 1 for both systems (1.6 and 2.1 for TMC-1 and TMC-2 catalysts, respectively) (Fig. 2 ). The number of active centers for both TMC increases with increasing of ethylene pressure in the analyzed pressure range (Table 1). Monomer pressure has almost no effect on the propagation rate constant in the pressure range of 1–4bar for TMC-1 catalyst (Table 1, runs 1 and 2); the increase in polymerization rate (divided on ethylene pressure) with pressure rising from 1 to 4bar is caused by a significant (2.2-fold) increase in the number of active centers. For TMC-2, a noticeable increase in the k P value is observed in the pressure range of 0.5–2bar, while the C P value changes slightly (Table 1, runs 3–5). When ethylene pressure is further increased, the k P value remains virtually unchanged (Table 1, runs 5 and 6) but a significant increase in the C P value is observed. Fig. 3 and Table 1 (run 7) show the data of the experiment where ethylene pressure was reduced from 4 to 1bar during polymerization. The polymerization rate decreased in accordance with the observed second order for the polymerization rate with respect to ethylene. The results obtained by determining the C P and k P values in this run at pressure of 1bar can be compared to those of runs 4 and 6 in Table 1 (conducted at 1 and 4bar, respectively). The C P values obtained in runs 7 and 4 at pressure of 1bar are close (0.20–0.22molmolTi −1) and are much lower than that in run 6, which was conducted at pressure of 4bar (0.40molmolTi −1). Thus, the number of active centers when the steady-state polymerization rate is achieved does not depend on the initial ethylene concentration at the stage of active center formation but changes with varied ethylene concentration during polymerization. The molecular weight distribution (MWD) was measured for the polymers produced over TMC-2 catalyst at different ethylene pressures (Fig. 4 , Table 1). It should be mentioned that measuring the M w value for polyethylene produced over TMC-1 catalyst is technically challenging because of the very high molecular weight: the estimated viscosity average molecular weight obtained by measuring the characteristic viscosity of the polymer in this case is 1.6×103 kgmol−1 (Table 1, run 2). In case of polymerization over TMC-2 catalyst one can see (Table 1) that an increase in monomer pressure results in a significant increase in molecular weight of the resulting polymer and MWD narrowing (Table 1, runs 3–6). The polymer produced at low ethylene pressure (0.5bar) contains a significant share of low-molecular-weight fraction (Fig. 4, curve 3, low-molecular-weight shoulder in the region of 103 kgmol−1). When ethylene pressure increases to 1 bar, the share of the low-molecular-weight fraction drops (Fig. 4, curve 4), while the average molecular weight of the total polymer increases. An increase in the calculated k P value is simultaneously observed in these experimental runs (Table 1, runs 3 and 4). An increase in ethylene pressure to 2bar causes further increase in the molecular weight and MWD narrowing, as well as an increase in the k P value (compare runs 4 and 5 in Table 1). When ethylene pressure is further increased to 4bar, the increase in M w and MWD narrowing become less significant, while the k P value remains virtually constant (compare runs 5 and 6 in Table 1). Thus, a significant contribution to the increase in the polymerization rate at ethylene polymerization over TMC-2 when ethylene pressure is increased from 0.5 to 2bar is made by the rise in the calculated propagation rate constant (Table 1, runs 3–5). The data on changes in the MWD of the polymers produced in the pressure range of 0.5–2bar (Fig. 4) indicate that several types of active centers are present in the system and ethylene concentration affects the share of polymer produced on each type of active centers. When ethylene concentration rises, the share of active centers producing low-molecular-weight polyethylene decreases, while the share of active centers producing high-molecular-weight polyethylene increases. So, the simultaneous increase in the calculated average k P value is attributable to the fact that active centers producing high-molecular-weight polyethylene have a higher k P value as compared to that producing low-molecular-weight polyethylene and the change in the ratio between these centers at increase in ethylene concentration increases the calculated average k P value. It should be noted that the presence of different active centers at ethylene polymerization over TMC was suggested in work [41] devoted to the MWD analysis of polymers. Data obtained demonstrate that the observed order of ethylene polymerization rate with respect to monomer higher than 1 (1.6–2.1) is not a true order of the propagation reaction and is caused by the effect of ethylene concentration on the number of active centers. In case of polymerization over TMC-2 catalyst, an additional increase in the order of the polymerization rate compared to TMC-1 catalyst is caused by a change in distribution of active centers with different k P values under variation of ethylene concentration. 3.2 Effect of AlEt3 concentration on the C P and k P values at different ethylene pressures Adsorption of an organoaluminum activator onto precursors of active centers (the alkylation products of titanium chloride) and onto active centers may be one of the possible reasons for changes in the C P and k P values with varied ethylene pressure. We studied the effect of concentration of AlEt3 activator at different ethylene pressure on the number of active centers and the propagation rate constant at ethylene polymerization over TMC-2 catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the kinetic profiles of ethylene polymerization over TMC-2 catalyst in the experimental runs with different AlEt3 concentrations (4.5 and 9.0mmolL−1). Two runs with different ethylene pressures (2 and 4bar) were carried out for each AlEt3 concentration. The data on the C P and k P values in these experiments are shown in Table 2 . High k P values, independent of ethylene pressure, are observed at low AlEt3 concentration (Table 2, runs 1 and 2). The number of active centers significantly rises with increasing of pressure (from 0.24 to 0.40molmolTi −1). In the experimental runs with elevated AlEt3 concentration (9mmolL−1), the propagation rate constant increases when ethylene pressure is varied from 2 to 4bar (Table 2, runs 3 and 4); however, even at 4bar it does not reach the k P value observed at low AlEt3 concentration (compare runs 4 and 2 in Table 2). The number of active centers at [AlEt3]=9mmolL−1 is independent of ethylene pressure and is close to the C P value at [AlEt3]=4.5mmolL−1 and ethylene pressure of 2bar (Table 2, run 1). Fig. 6 shows the molecular weight distribution curves of the polymers produced at different AlEt3 concentrations and different ethylene pressures. One can see that the contribution of the low-molecular-weight shoulder at 103 kgmol−1 to the total polymer decreases both when pressure is increased from 2 to 4bar at constant AlEt3 concentration (Fig. 6a and 6b) and when AlEt3 concentration is reduced from 9 to 4.5mmolL−1 at constant ethylene pressure of 2bar (Fig. 6c). Simultaneously, the MWD is narrowed and the M n value increases (compare pairwise runs 1 and 2, 3 and 4, 3 and 1 in Table 2). The greatest decrease in contribution of the low-molecular-weight shoulder, as well as MWD narrowing are observed in the runs with ethylene pressure of 2bar when AlEt3 concentration is reduced (Fig. 6c, Table 2, runs 3 and 1). Data on the MWD narrowing and increase of M n value in run 1 in comparison with run 3 correlate with the strong increase of k P value in run 1 in comparison with run 3 (Table 2). Thus, both AlEt3 and ethylene concentrations have a significant effect on the number of active centers, the calculated k P value, M n value and the molecular weight distribution of polymers. We believe that this effect can be explained by different abilities of the active centers to reversibly adsorb the organoaluminum activator, yielding temporarily inactive structures that can be activated as ethylene concentration is increased. Adsorption processes affect the number of active centers and distribution of active centers with different k P value. The tentative scheme of the reactions occurring is shown below. 3.3 Tentative scheme of the reactions resulting in a change in the C P and k P values at varied concentrations of ethylene and AlEt3. The kinetic findings allow us to propose Scheme 1 for the reactions occurring at ethylene polymerization over TMC-1 and TMC-2. These reactions proceed to changing the number of active centers and the average value of propagation rate constant when ethylene pressure and AlEt3 concentration are varied. Alkylation of titanium chloride with an organoaluminum activator gives rise to precursors of active centers C pr containing the Ti–Et bond. These precursors may either immediately join the propagation reaction (1) or be blocked during adsorption of an organoaluminium compound via reaction (2), giving rise to inactive C pr Al structures. These centers can become active again by interacting with ethylene via reaction (3). At high AlEt3 concentration and low ethylene pressure, the equilibrium of reactions (2) and (3) is shifted towards the formation of inactive C pr Al structures and the noticeable part of titanium is inactive. When monomer concentration increases or AlEt3 concentration decreases, the equilibrium of reactions (2) and (3) is shifted towards the formation of active centers C P or their precursors C pr that are not blocked by the organoaluminum compound, which subsequently join the chain propagation reaction (1). The organoaluminum activator can block both precursors of active centers C pr via reaction (2) and the active centers C P via reaction (4). This is accompanied by formation of temporarily inactive structures C P Al (the so-called dormant sites), and the chain propagation temporarily stops. These dormant sites can be activated by interaction with ethylene via reaction (5). At low ethylene pressure, the equilibrium of reactions (4) and (5) is shifted towards the formation of structures C P Al, and some active centers are temporarily inactive (dormant). Since these centers contain the titanium–polymer bond, they interact with carbon monoxide in a same manner as the functioning active centers C P do. Hence, the sum of active centers C P and dormant sites C P Al is determined under these conditions by quenching with 14CO. In this case, the calculated k P value depends on the ratio between the C P and C P Al values; k P is lower when the contribution of C P Al is high as compared to the conditions when this contribution is insignificant. The emergence of dormant sites C P Al gives rise to a significant share of low-molecular-weight polymer fraction, which is observed for the polymers produced at low ethylene pressure and high AlEt3 concentration (Figs. 4 and 6). When monomer pressure increases and AlEt3 concentration decreases, the equilibrium of reactions (4) and (5) is shifted towards the formation of active sites C P, and the portion of dormant sites is decreased. This increases the calculated k P value, reduces the share of the low-molecular-weight fraction in the polymer and MWD narrowing. When the portion of dormant sites becomes negligible, the k P value becomes constant (Table 1, runs 5 and 6). The proposed scheme allows one to interpret the effect of monomer pressure on the C P and k P values at ethylene polymerization over the catalysts under study. Let us assume that adsorption of AlEt3 onto active centers is weaker than adsorption of AlEt3 onto precursors of active centers (probably due to steric reasons). In this case, if ethylene pressure is increased, AlEt3 will be first desorbed from active centers (thus increasing the observed k P value) and subsequently from their precursors (increasing the C P value). According to the data listed in Table 1, ethylene pressure increased in the range of 0.5–1bar for TMC-2 significantly increases the k P value; the C P value changes negligibly (runs 3 and 4). The MWD curve at this moment shows a significant share of low-molecular-weight fraction of the polymer (Fig. 4, runs 3 and 4), which is formed as the propagation reaction on the active centers blocked by AlEt3 is stopped. At ethylene pressure of 2bar, k P becomes maximal (Table 1, run 5). When pressure is further increased to 4bar (Table 1, run 6), a significant increase in C P and a decrease in the share of the low-molecular-weight fraction in the polymer are observed (Fig. 4, runs 5 and 6). According to the scheme, it means that ethylene pressure of 2bar is sufficient for TMC-2 to shift the equilibrium of reaction (5) to the right but is insufficient to shift the equilibrium of reaction (3) to the right. For TMC-1 catalyst, the k P value in the pressure range under study (1–4bar) remains unchanged (Table 1, runs 1 and 2); i.e., ethylene pressure of 1bar is sufficient to shift the equilibrium of reaction (5) over this catalyst to the right and the further increase in monomer pressure causes a rightward shift of the equilibrium of reaction (3). In other words, desorption of AlEt3 from precursors of active centers can be started only when active centers are free of AlEt3 (average k P value becomes maximal). The effect of AlEt3 concentration on the C P and k P values can be explained in a similar way (Table 2). For low concentration of the organoaluminum activator, ethylene pressure of 2bar is sufficient to minimize AlEt3 adsorption onto active centers; hence, k P does not increase when pressure rises to 4bar and reaches its highest value (Table 2, runs 1 and 2). Meanwhile, AlEt3 is desorbed from the precursors of active centers, thus increasing the C P value (Table 2, runs 1 and 2). At higher AlEt3 concentrations, ethylene pressure of 4bar is insufficient for organoaluminum to be desorbed from active centers and especially from their precursors; hence, the C P value is low and does not depend on ethylene pressure (Table 2, runs 3 and 4), while the k P value increases with pressure but remains lower than that at low AOC concentration (compare runs 4 and 2 in Table 2). The obtained experimental data on the reversible changes of the number of active centers at change of ethylene concentration during polymerization (Fig. 3, Table 1, run 7 in comparison with runs 4 and 6) confirm that in catalysts under study the reversible reactions proceed. These reactions affect the number of active centers and depend on ethylene concentration. Thus, the kinetic findings give grounds for assuming that two reversible processes occur in the systems under study: AlEt3 adsorption onto precursors of active centers containing the Ti–Et bond (reaction (2)) and the stop of propagation reaction owing to AlEt3 adsorption onto active centers containing the Ti–polymer bond (reaction (4)). Increased monomer concentration shifts the equilibrium of these processes towards desorption of AlEt3, which increases the number of active centers (for the former process) and the average propagation rate constant (for the latter one). 4 Conclusions The effect of monomer concentration (pressure) on activity at ethylene polymerization, the number of active centers, and the propagation rate constant has been studied using two modifications of supported titanium-magnesium catalysts differing in their compositions and preparation method. These catalysts exhibit different activities and produce polyethylene with different molecular weight. Nonlinear dependence of the polymerization rate on monomer concentration is observed for both catalysts: the observed order of the reaction rate with respect to monomer is much higher than 1 (1.6–2.1). It has been found that the observed high order of the polymerization rate with respect to monomer is due to the increased number of active centers caused by an increase in ethylene pressure. Meanwhile, it was established for one of the catalysts that decreased ethylene pressure and increased AlEt3 concentration result in a decrease in the calculated propagation rate constant and formation of a significant share of low-molecular-weight fraction in the polymer. The emergence of centers producing low-molecular-weight polyethylene with low reactivity decreases the average k P value calculated for the centers producing both low- and high-molecular-weight PE. Based on the joint analysis of the resulting kinetic data and the data on polymer MWD, we proposed a scheme explaining the effect of concentrations of the monomer and organoaluminum activator on the C P and k P values at ethylene polymerization over the studied TMC. This scheme includes two reversible processes: (1) adsorption of an organoaluminum compound onto precursors of active centers containing the titanium–ethyl bond and (2) temporary stop of chain propagation due to coordination of the organoaluminum compound on the functioning active centers containing the active titanium–polymer bond. The obtained experimental data on the reversible changes of the number of active centers at change of ethylene concentration during polymerization confirm that in catalysts under study the reversible reactions proceed. These reactions affect the number of active centers and depend on ethylene concentration. Acknowledgements The authors are grateful to T.B. Mikenas for affording the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: It was found that the observed order of the polymerization rate with respect to ethylene concentration at ethylene polymerization over two titanium-magnesium catalysts of different compositions is significantly higher than 1 (1.6–2.1). The data on the effect of ethylene concentration on the number of active centers (C P) and the propagation rate constant (k P) at ethylene polymerization over these catalysts were obtained by method of polymerization quenching with 14CO. An increase in ethylene concentration was found to increase the number of active centers. In some cases the increase of ethylene concentration proceeds to the narrowing of the molecular weight distribution of the resulting polyethylene and an increase in the calculated value of propagation rate constant. These effects were shown to be most pronounced at low ethylene pressure and increased concentration of an activator (AlEt3). Based on the experimental data, we proposed a scheme of reactions to explain the effects of ethylene and AlR3 concentrations on the number of active centers, the average values of propagation rate constant and molecular weight distribution of polymers produced over these multi-site catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic features of ethylene polymerization over titanium-magnesium Ziegler-Natta catalysts: Effect of monomer concentration on the number of active centers and propagation rate constant
